docs.lead_paragraph: A state analysis of insurers in New York shows that Cigna had the highest ratio of upheld customer complaints among health insurers in 2000. The New York Consumer Guide to Health Insurers identifies the number of complaints, the number upheld by state regulators and other information on the health insurance industry. Overall, consumers made 11,101 complaints to the State Insurance Department in 2000, typically about payments, reimbursements, coverage, benefits, rates and premiums. Of those, the state upheld 3,245, about the same level as in 1999, said a department spokeswoman, JoAnna Rose. Cigna had 174 of 704 complaints upheld. The companies with the next worst ratios were MDNY, with 118 of 607 complaints upheld; Vytra, with 162 of 1,059; Oxford, with 1,461 of 4,065; and PHS (Health Net), with 125 of 450. The report said Rochester Area HMO (Preferred Care) had the best complaint ratio in 2000, with none of five complaints upheld, followed by Managed Health, Metroplus, Finger Lakes HMO/HMO Blue and Univera Healthcare of Central New York.

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing | Insurance Complaint Rankings

docs.lead_paragraph: Jamie Marie Smith was 19 when she gave birth on the floor of her trailer home here last December, hours after leaving her night-shift job. Her 2-year-old son was the only one with her. The next night, Ms. Smith, who is not married, went looking for somewhere to leave her baby. She settled on a brightly lighted apartment complex. There, in an empty hallway, she left the sleeping infant in a cardboard box.

headline.main: Few Choose Legal Havens to Abandon Babies

docs.abstract: Safe haven laws intended to protect abandoned newborns, adopted by 35 states in last two years, do not seem to be having desired effect; of first 16 states that passed laws, only six report safe haven babies in survey by National Conference of State Legislatures; babies continue to be abandoned illegally in states with safe haven laws--more frequently, in some cases, than in states without them; laws were passed in reaction to number of attention-getting cases in which abandoned newborns were found dead; politicians and advocates found spirit of legislation easy to embrace, but speed of laws' acceptance left little time for thorough discussion of whether they work, or even dimensions of problem they were intended to address; fact is that babies found dead or discarded in unsafe places are tiny portion of those abandoned; most are left safely in hospitals; New York, New Jersey and Connecticut are among states that have adopted safe haven law; photos; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of the AremisSoft Corporation resumed trading today after a monthlong halt caused by a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation. They immediately fell in value 91 percent. The stock fell $10.19, to $1 a share, with 16.5 million shares changing hands, the busiest trading in the company's stock since it went public in 1999. They last traded at $11.19 on July 27. The stock was delisted from the Nasdaq stock market today, and traded over the counter instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last five years, the number of uninsured women has grown three times faster than the number of uninsured men, according to a new study by the Commonwealth Fund. If coverage trends continue, the report said, the number of uninsured women will surpass the number of uninsured men by 2005. ''It's clear to me that having now made real progress on covering children, the next priorities are mothers and low-income women generally,'' said Karen Davis, president of the Commonwealth Fund, a nonprofit health research group based in New York. ''Women are more in need of preventive services at a younger age than men, tied in with their reproductive health care.''

headline.main: More Women Are Losing Insurance Than Men

docs.lead_paragraph: If there is an American Dream, then Audrey Boothe believes she has found perhaps the one place in New York where it is still attainable on a teacher's salary. In Canarsie, a neighborhood in southeastern Brooklyn, Ms. Boothe, a 39-year-old Jamaican immigrant, owns a $165,000 three-bedroom home with a driveway and backyard. And she is able to save from her $37,000 salary just enough to send her 7-year-old son, Obassi, to private martial arts and drumming classes. ''It's a wonderful piece of the dream without having to move out to Long Island or Jersey,'' she said.

headline.main: Voters Focus on Better Schools; A Changing Canarsie Wants Mayor to Ease Crowding

docs.abstract: Article discusses how voters in Canarsie section of Brooklyn see upcoming New York City mayoral election; majority expresses concern over candidates focus on better schools; maintains that major problem in city's schools is overcrowding; photo; map (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate of the Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded for The New York Times. The debate was organized by the New York City Campaign Finance Board for candidates who receive public money, and was sponsored by WPIX-TV (Channel 11), WNYC-AM Radio (820) and Newsday. It was moderated by Kaity Tong, co-anchor of ''WB11 News at 10.'' The candidates were questioned by Brian Lehrer, host of WNYC's ''On the Line''; Les Payne, deputy managing editor at Newsday; and Jim Watkins, co-anchor of ''WB11 News at 10.'' Q. Let's say just hypothetically the squeegee men think that with the Giuliani administration gone, for them the coast is clear. Please tell us the steps you would take.

docs.lead_paragraph: The CVS Corporation has agreed to pay $4 million to settle allegations it submitted false prescription claims, the government said yesterday. CVS and the Revco chain it acquired in 1997 have been accused of dispensing partial prescriptions because of insufficient stock, while billing government health insurance programs for the full quantities prescribed, the Justice Department said. The settlement covers the period between Jan. 1, 1988, and June 1, 1997. The settlement money will go to the federal government, the District of Columbia and 20 states. A portion also will go to settle an individual's complaint against Revco.

headline.main: CVS TO PAY $4 MILLION TO SETTLE PRESCRIPTION CHARGES
